title: Discovery – Prepositions with the Accusative (Motion Toward)
goals: Recognize Latin prepositions that use the accusative case
Understand motion-toward meaning (ad, in, per, super, ante)
Connect grammatical order to moral order – Ordō

steps.speak: Salve! Welcome to Week 14 Day 1. We begin a new adventure — learning small words called prepositions that show direction and place.
Some prepositions use the accusative case to show motion toward something.
For example, ad means ‘to’ or ‘toward’. Say: ad puellam – to the girl.
Notice the ending –am again! That’s our accusative form from earlier weeks.
Try these with me: in agrum (into the field), per viam (through the road), super aquam (over the water), ante domum (before the house).
Each shows movement — something going toward or across another thing.
Now combine with verbs: Puer ambulat ad domum – The boy walks to the house.
Puella currit per viam – The girl runs through the road.
Faith phrase: Ad Dominum currimus – We run to the Lord.
Virtue reflection: God orders our steps toward Him, just as Latin prepositions show the right direction.
Chant endings: -a → -am, -us → -um. These help show motion toward.
Optime! Tomorrow we’ll build longer sentences using these new prepositions.
